page.title: 16The Black Mountain.
page.content: North of the village of Glanaman lies the Black Mountain, a range of hills which form the westerly extent of the Brecon Beacons National Park. The mountain provides excellent walking country, being crisscrossed by many unfenced roads and footpaths. The flora consists mainly of grasses, sedges and heathers, although many interesting plants, such as the sundew and butterwort are to be found. Weather conditions can be extreme. Consequently, the hills are mainly used for the summer grazing of sheep. Recently, attempts have been made to sell off hundred-acre parcels of the Black Mountain to private owners, who would be bound by the regulations of the National Park Authority. Local feeling has been divided on this issue, as large tracts of land may be bought up by foreign concerns.
